title: 109_hr3509
content: The Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2006 may be cited as the Act. It includes a statute of repose for durable goods used in a trade or business. The Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2006, also known as the Act, establishes a statute of repose for durable goods used in a trade or business. It limits civil actions against manufacturers or sellers of durable goods for property damage or personal injury to within 12 years of the goods being delivered to the first purchaser or lessee, provided the injury does not involve toxic harm and the claimant has received or is eligible for worker compensation. Exceptions to the Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2006 include certain vehicles used for passenger transport, civil actions based on express warranties lasting over 12 years, limitations set by the General Aviation Revitalization Act of 1994, and actions related to the environment. The Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2006 has exceptions for certain vehicles and express warranties lasting over 12 years. It does not affect regulatory enforcement actions or actions for environmental remediation. Additionally, it does not prevent civil actions against manufacturers who fraudulently conceal defects in durable goods. This Act preempts and supersedes any State laws related to these provisions. This Act preempts and supersedes any State law related to statute of repose for actions covered by this Act. Any action not covered by this Act will be governed by applicable State or Federal law. A transitional provision allows claimants to bring actions not later than 1 year after the enactment of this Act if it shortens the period for bringing civil actions. The curr_chunk is a section titled "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." In this Act, a "claimant" is defined as any person bringing an action covered by the Act, including representatives of estates, minors, or incompetents. A "durable good" is described as a product with a life expectancy of 3 or more years, subject to depreciation, and used in a trade or business. The term "fraudulently concealed" with respect to a durable good means the manufacturer or seller had knowledge of a defect, the defect caused harm, and they intentionally hid the defect. The term "seller" refers to any dealer, retailer, wholesaler, or distributor involved in the sale or lease of a durable good to the end-user in the stream of commerce. The term "State" includes all states of the United States, territories, possessions, and political subdivisions. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF ACT. This Act will take effect upon enactment, regardless of when the damage or injury occurred. It does not apply to civil actions initiated before enactment.
